Simulating Shares from Estimated Models

Source: vignettes/simulations.Rmd
simulations.Rmd

Once a model has been estimated, it can be used to simulate the predicted shares for a set of alternatives. This vignette demonstrates examples of how to so using the simulateShares() function along with the results of an estimated model.

The data

To simulate shares, you first need to create a set of alternatives where each row is an alternative and each column an attribute. In this example, I just use a couple of the choice observations from the yogurt dataset (note that if you include more than one set of alternatives you also have to specify an obsID):

alts <- subset(yogurt, obsID %in% c(42, 13),
               select = c('obsID', 'price', 'feat', 'brand'))
alts
#>     obsID price feat   brand
#> 49     13   8.1    0  dannon
#> 50     13   5.0    0  hiland
#> 51     13   8.6    0  weight
#> 52     13  10.8    0 yoplait
#> 165    42   6.3    0  dannon
#> 166    42   6.1    1  hiland
#> 167    42   7.9    0  weight
#> 168    42  11.5    0 yoplait

Simulating shares with multinomial logit models

Preference space parameterization

In the example below, I estimate a preference space MNL model called mnl_pref. I can then use the simulateShares() function with the mnl_pref model to predict the shares for each set of alternatives in the alts data frame:

# Estimate the model
mnl_pref <- logitr(
  data       = yogurt,
  choiceName = 'choice',
  obsIDName  = 'obsID',
  parNames   = c('price', 'feat', 'brand')
)

# Simulate shares
sim_mnl_pref <- simulateShares(
  model     = mnl_pref,
  alts      = alts,
  obsIDName = "obsID",
  alpha     = 0.025
)
sim_mnl_pref
#>   obsID share_mean  share_low share_high
#> 1     1 0.43684871 0.39244231 0.47914424
#> 2     1 0.03313009 0.02538150 0.04255726
#> 3     1 0.19155738 0.17218226 0.21154713
#> 4     1 0.33846382 0.28243730 0.39870527
#> 5     2 0.60763975 0.54685397 0.66119100
#> 6     2 0.02602079 0.01865065 0.03588004
#> 7     2 0.17803594 0.16280894 0.19387289
#> 8     2 0.18830353 0.13929013 0.24882718

The results show the expected shares for each alternative. The low and high values show a 95% confidence interval, estimated using simulation. You can change the CI level by setting alpha to a different value (e.g. a 90% CI is obtained with alpha = 0.05).

WTP space parameterization

You can also use WTP space models to simulate shares, but you must provide the additional priceName argument to the simulateShares() function. For example, here are the results from an equivalent model but in the WTP space:

# Estimate the model
mnl_wtp <- logitr(
  data       = yogurt,
  choiceName = 'choice',
  obsIDName  = 'obsID',
  parNames   = c('feat', 'brand'),
  priceName  = 'price',
  modelSpace = 'wtp',
  options = list(numMultiStarts = 10)
)

# Simulate shares
sim_mnl_wtp <- simulateShares(
  model     = mnl_wtp,
  alts      = alts,
  obsIDName = "obsID",
  priceName = 'price'
)
#> NOTE: Using results from run 8 of 10 multistart runs
#> (the run with the largest log-likelihood value)
sim_mnl_wtp
#>   obsID share_mean  share_low share_high
#> 1     1 0.43685988 0.41471551 0.45737046
#> 2     1 0.03312953 0.02643618 0.04224245
#> 3     1 0.19154714 0.17610340 0.20761726
#> 4     1 0.33846344 0.31871639 0.35849361
#> 5     2 0.60767025 0.57469492 0.63700526
#> 6     2 0.02601826 0.01881347 0.03776785
#> 7     2 0.17802280 0.16150788 0.19522001
#> 8     2 0.18828870 0.16653604 0.20947105

Since these two models are equivalent except in different spaces, the simulation results should be the same.

Predicting with mixed logit models

Preference space parameterization

You can also use mixed logit models to simulate shares. Heterogeneity is modeled by simulating draws from the population estimates of the estimated model. Here is an example using a preference space mixed logit model:

# Estimate the model
mxl_pref <- logitr(
  data       = yogurt,
  choiceName = 'choice',
  obsIDName  = 'obsID',
  parNames   = c('price', 'feat', 'brand'),
  randPars   = c(feat = 'n', brand = 'n'),
  options    = list(numMultiStarts = 5)
)

# Simulate shares
sim_mxl_pref <- simulateShares(
  model     = mxl_pref,
  alts      = alts,
  obsIDName = "obsID"
)
sim_mxl_pref
#>   obsID share_mean  share_low share_high
#> 1     1 0.45230084 0.34966229 0.53637531
#> 2     1 0.02782708 0.02115254 0.09031944
#> 3     1 0.21027296 0.07373199 0.33215482
#> 4     1 0.30959912 0.25024703 0.38030701
#> 5     2 0.60391759 0.44147888 0.72868762
#> 6     2 0.06797893 0.02712724 0.14482994
#> 7     2 0.18726035 0.05996165 0.31026344
#> 8     2 0.14084313 0.10513560 0.22080828

WTP space parameterization

Likewise, mixed logit WTP space models can also be used to simulate shares:

# Estimate the model
mxl_wtp <- logitr(
  data       = yogurt,
  choiceName = 'choice',
  obsIDName  = 'obsID',
  parNames   = c('feat', 'brand'),
  priceName  = 'price',
  randPars   = c(feat = 'n', brand = 'n'),
  modelSpace = 'wtp',
  options    = list(numMultiStarts = 5)
)

# Simulate shares
sim_mxl_wtp <- simulateShares(
  model     = mxl_wtp,
  alts      = alts,
  obsIDName = "obsID",
  priceName = 'price'
)
sim_mxl_wtp
#>   obsID share_mean  share_low share_high
#> 1     1 0.44009485 0.36547752 0.50016971
#> 2     1 0.02680642 0.02088098 0.07033526
#> 3     1 0.20352286 0.08398833 0.31741687
#> 4     1 0.32957587 0.27729743 0.38773239
#> 5     2 0.58694687 0.47232637 0.67239114
#> 6     2 0.08160428 0.03379105 0.16675942
#> 7     2 0.18184019 0.07046588 0.29287607
#> 8     2 0.14960865 0.11600390 0.20098719

Compare results

Here is a bar plot comparing the simulated shares from each model:

library(ggplot2)

sims <- rbind(sim_mnl_pref, sim_mnl_wtp, sim_mxl_pref, sim_mxl_wtp)
sims <- sims[sims$obsID == 1,]
sims$model <- c(rep("mnl_pref", 4), rep("mnl_wtp", 4),
                rep("mxl_pref", 4), rep("mxl_wtp", 4))
sims$alt <- rep(c("dannon", "hiland", "weight", "yoplait"), 4)

ggplot(sims, aes(x = alt, y = share_mean, fill = model)) +
    geom_bar(stat = 'identity', width = 0.7, position = "dodge") +
    geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = share_low, ymax = share_high),
                  width = 0.2, position = position_dodge(width = 0.7)) +
    scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 1)) +
    labs(x = 'Alternative', y = 'Expected Share') +
    theme_bw()
